conclusion: Initial conditions: height of each chamber is H, volume is V, pressure is p, temperature is T, mass of diaphragm is m.
Force applied to piston causes diaphragm to move downwards by h, increasing pressure in upper chamber.
Pressure increase in upper chamber calculated as Δp = ρgh, where ρ is density of helium.
Volume of lower chamber decreases by hA when piston is raised by h, new volume is V_0 = V - hA.
Equilibrium condition before gas leakage: pressure in upper chamber equals pressure in lower chamber plus additional pressure.
Condition for gas leakage: pressure in upper chamber must be greater than pressure in lower chamber.
Solving for V_0 using relation x = mgH/pV, express Δp in terms of x.
Substitute Δp back into pressure equation and simplify inequality to find V_0.
Rearrange to solve for V_0: V_0 > V^2/(V + xH).
